title: 114_s3201
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commodity Checkoff Program Improvement Act of 2016". Congress finds that generic checkoff programs are intended to increase demand for agricultural commodities and benefit producers. However, these programs have been found to use funds to influence policy, which harms some producers. To prevent misuse of funds, there should be strict separation of engagement between the Boards. Checkoff programs should have strict separation between Boards and policy entities to prevent conflicts of interest and ensure lawful operation. Transparency is lacking in checkoff programs, allowing for misuse of funds. Anticompetitive conduct should be prohibited to maintain the proper operation of checkoff programs. Lack of transparency in checkoff programs enables and conceals abuses, necessitating transparency in expenditure to prevent and uncover such abuses. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "Board" as an entity for checkoff programs and "Checkoff program" as a promotional program for agricultural commodities without specific producers or brands mentioned. It includes programs like the Cotton Research and Promotion Act, Potato Research and Promotion Act, Egg Research and Consumer Information Act, and Beef Research and Information Act. The curr_chunk lists various agricultural acts such as the Wheat and Wheat Foods Research Act, Floral Research Act, Dairy Production Stabilization Act, Honey Research Act, Pork Promotion Act, Watermelon Research Act, Pecan Promotion Act, and Mushroom Promotion Act. The curr_chunk lists various agricultural acts including the Mushroom Promotion Act of 1990, Lime Research Act, Soybean Promotion Act, Fluid Milk Promotion Act, Fresh Cut Flowers and Fresh Cut Greens Promotion Act, Sheep Promotion Act, and Commodity Promotion Act. The curr_chunk discusses different agricultural acts such as the Canola and Rapeseed Research Act, National Kiwifruit Research Act, Popcorn Promotion Act, and Hass Avocado Promotion Act. It also defines "conflict of interest" as a financial interest in a person or entity working with a Board. The curr_chunk defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture. The curr_chunk states prohibitions and requirements for the publication of budgets and disbursements. The curr_chunk outlines prohibitions for Boards regarding contracts, conflicts of interest, anticompetitive activities, unfair practices, and disparaging acts. The Board must publish approved budgets and disbursements, disclosing the amount, purpose, recipient, and other parties involved in receiving funds. The Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture conducts periodic audits to ensure compliance of each checkoff program with the regulations. Reports are prepared describing the audit findings. The Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture conducts periodic audits to ensure compliance with checkoff program regulations. A report is prepared and submitted to Congress, including the Subcommittee on Antitrust, Competition Policy, and Consumer Rights, and the Comptroller General of the United States. The Comptroller General will conduct an audit not earlier than 3 years and not later than 5 years after the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General of the United States shall conduct an audit to assess the status of actions taken for each checkoff program to ensure compliance and improve program integrity. A report will be prepared with recommendations to strengthen these actions. The Comptroller General of the United States will consider inspector general reports when making recommendations to improve Federal legislation on checkoff programs. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected.
